SCABBARD AND BLADE
TO SPONSOR DANCE
Scabbard and Blade will
sponsor the regular Saturday
night dance usually held under
the auspices of the Cotillion
Club on March 2 from 9-1
P.M. _
Bob Iula in person and his
orchestra will provide the music. Tickets are $1.00 stag or
couple.
The dance is not closed hut
merely sponsored by the Scabbard and Blade: all Hopkins
men are invited.

BUSINESS STAFF
TO MEET MONDAY
Next Monday there will be
a very important meeting of
the entire Business Staff of
the NEWS-NLETTER at 12:30 in
the NEWS-LETTER office at the
Barn. This, meeting is most
important, as the elections of
next year's Board of Control
will be discussed. All members of this staff should make
it their business to attend.

AST month, the scrappy Blue Jay basketball team invaded the
gymnasium at College Park and tossed a -veritable bombshell
into the ranks 'of the enemy. When the smoke had cleared away, the
Maryland players discovered themselves humiliated and beaten by a
30 to 20 score. From the first doubledecker, scored by Captain Lang,
to the last goal, made by Jung, the Ravens were, outplayed and outfought. •
Tomorrow afternoon, the Maryland basketers will be seeking revenge, on the Jays' home court at Carlin's. According to the information divulged by Paul Menton and other sports experts, the Washington Boulevard players are confident of victory. On the other hand,
the Jays, in spite of recent disheartening defeats, are prepared to resist the enemy. .
'With both of the ancient rivals displaying their usual skill and
aggressiveness, a high old time is in store for those who journey out
to the amusement park tomorrow afternoon. All signs indicate that
the Jay-Raven clash will be one of the most interesting and exciting
contests of the current basketball season.

SIGNS OF PROGRESS
HE arrival of a giant motor shovel on the site of the former
tennis courts, indicates that the actual construction work on the
new Physics Building will soon commence. Meanwhile, farther up the
road, the sound of carpenters' hammers and the clatter of concrete
mixers resound across the campus as Levering Hall slowly rises.
This building activity is an outward and visible sign of the University's progress. Before many months, the Homewood campus will
present an entirely different aspect to the casual visitor.
.antime, members of the June Week committee assume
In the c.i ,
deep frown nd worried expressions as they survey the scene of operations. After all, picks, shovels, wheelbarrows, brick piles, concrete
bags and board fences di, not provide very romantic surroundings for
du annual festival of the graduating class.

AST month, the scrappy Blue Jay basketball team invaded the
gymnasium at College Park and tossed a -veritable bombshell
into the ranks 'of the enemy. When the smoke had cleared away, the
Maryland players discovered themselves humiliated and beaten by a
30 to 20 score. From the first doubledecker, scored by Captain Lang,
to the last goal, made by Jung, the Ravens were, outplayed and outfought. •
Tomorrow afternoon, the Maryland basketers will be seeking revenge, on the Jays' home court at Carlin's. According to the information divulged by Paul Menton and other sports experts, the Washington Boulevard players are confident of victory. On the other hand,
the Jays, in spite of recent disheartening defeats, are prepared to resist the enemy. .
'With both of the ancient rivals displaying their usual skill and
aggressiveness, a high old time is in store for those who journey out
to the amusement park tomorrow afternoon. All signs indicate that
the Jay-Raven clash will be one of the most interesting and exciting
contests of the current basketball season.

SIGNS OF PROGRESS
HE arrival of a giant motor shovel on the site of the former
tennis courts, indicates that the actual construction work on the
new Physics Building will soon commence. Meanwhile, farther up the
road, the sound of carpenters' hammers and the clatter of concrete
mixers resound across the campus as Levering Hall slowly rises.
This building activity is an outward and visible sign of the University's progress. Before many months, the Homewood campus will
present an entirely different aspect to the casual visitor.

bags and board fences di, not provide very romantic surroundings for
